meanings.definition: The act of preempting or forestalling something
meanings.sent1: The preemption of the last cookie by Sarah left everyone else disappointed.
meanings.sent2: The company's preemption of the market trend helped them stay ahead of competitors.
meanings.sent3: John's preemption of the best seat in the movie theater caused a playful argument among friends.
meanings.sent4: The preemption of the final piece in the puzzle completed the picture perfectly.
meanings.sent5: The preemption of the only available parking spot made finding a space challenging.

meanings.definition: The purchase of goods or shares by one person or party before the opportunity is offered to others
meanings.sent1: His preemption of the limited edition sneakers made him the envy of his friends.
meanings.sent2: The preemption of the stocks before the market opened proved to be a wise investment.
meanings.sent3: The preemption of the last slice of pizza at the party earned him the title of 'Pizza King'.
meanings.sent4: Her preemption of the concert tickets ensured they had front-row seats.
meanings.sent5: The preemption of the rare comic book left collectors scrambling to find a copy.

meanings.definition: The right of a government to seize or appropriate property for public use before the owner can object
meanings.sent1: The city's preemption of the land for the new park was met with mixed reactions from residents.
meanings.sent2: The preemption of private property for road construction is a common practice by the government.
meanings.sent3: The preemption of the historic building for restoration sparked a debate on preservation efforts.
meanings.sent4: The government's preemption of the abandoned factory for redevelopment revitalized the area.
meanings.sent5: The preemption of the farmland for a new airport faced opposition from local farmers.
